raw_text:
SA return to Mauritius
 
 Top seeds South Africa return to the scene of one of their most embarrassing failures when they face the Seychelles in the Cosafa Cup next month.
 
 Last year Bafana Bafana were humbled in the first by minnows Mauritius who beat them 2-0 in Curepipe. Coach Stuart Baxter and his squad will return to Curepipe face the Seychelles in their first game of the new-look regional competition. The format of the event has been changed this year after the entry of the Seychelles, who have taken the number of participants to 13. The teams are now divided into three group of four and play knock-out matches on successive days to determine the group champions. Mauritius host the first group, and their opponents are Madagascar, the Seychelles and South Africa. Bafana Bafana play the Seychelles before Mauritius take on Madagascar in a double-header on 26 February. The two winners return to the New George V stadium the next day and the victor of the group decider advances to August's final mini-tournament. The second group will be hosted in Namibia in April. It comprises Zimbabwe, Botswana, Mozambique and the hosts. In June, former champions Zambia will host Lesotho, Malawi and Swaziland in the third group in Lusaka. The three group winners will then join title holders Angola for the last of the mini-tournaments in August, where the winners will be crowned.
 
 Seychelles v South Africa
 
 Mauritius v Madagascar
 
 Winners meet in final match
 
 Mozambique v Zimbabwe
 
 Namibia v Botswana
 
 Winners meet in final match
 
 Lesotho v Malawi
 
 Zambia v Swaziland
 
 Winners meet in final match
llama3.2:1b: South Africa return to the Cosafa Cup next month. They face Seychelles, who won 2-0 against them last year. The format has changed with 13 teams divided into three groups of four for knock-out matches. Mauritius host the first group and will play Madagascar on February 26.
llama3.2:3b: South Africa returns to Mauritius for the Cosafa Cup, having been defeated 2-0 by Mauritius last year. The teams are divided into three groups of four and play knock-out matches. The format has changed with the addition of Seychelles.
gemma2:2b: The Cosafa Cup returns with 13 participating teams. South Africa plays Seychelles first, then Mauritius will play Madagascar to determine the group champions in a double-header on February 26th.  Winners advance to August's final mini-tournament, while the remaining groups in Namibia and Zambia host their respective tournaments in April and June respectively. The final tournament will see winners from each group meet for the title.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Top seeds South Africa return to their home ground, Curepipe, next month. Their opponents are Seychelles and Mauritius in the Cosafa Cup. The format of the tournament has changed this year with Seychelles having 13 teams. South Africa host Seychelles first on February 26, followed by Madagascar on April 19. Winners will face each other at Lusaka's final mini-tournament, where they win their group and qualify for August's final.
qwen2.5:1.5b: South Africa, ranked top seeds, returns to the Cosafa Cup in Mauritius for matches against Seychelles and Madagascar. The tournament format includes two double-headers, with winners advancing to a final match that determines the overall winner.
qwen2.5:3b: SA return to Mauritius for the Cosafa Cup, facing Seychelles after their humiliating 2-0 loss last year. This year's format includes three groups of four teams each, with winners advancing to a mini-tournament in August where the group winners compete for titles. Matches so far: Seychelles vs SA, Mauritius vs Madagascar; Mozambique vs Zimbabwe and Namibia vs Botswana, Lesotho vs Malawi and Zambia vs Swaziland. The winners of these matches advance to the final round in August.

Top seeds South Africa return to the Cosafa Cup next month against Seychelles.

 winners from each group compete in August's mini-tournament.

tinyllama:1.1b: SA return to the scene of their most embarrassing failure when they face Seychelles in the Cosafa Cup next month. Last year Bafanas humbled by minnow Mauritius, who defeated them 2-0 in Curupipe. This year, they will return to Curupipe for a first game against the Seychelles in their first group of four matches. Mauritius host Seychelles before Zimbabwe, Botswana, Mozambique and the hosts enter the New George V stadium the next day. The second group comprises former champions Zambia, who will host Lesotho, Malawi, and SwaziLand in June. The three group winners will join title holder Angola for the final mini-tournament in August, where the winner meets the loser of a semifinal match between Mozambique and Zimbabwe.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Seychelles vs. South Africa: The Cosafa Cup is set to be a thrilling encounter between the Seychelles and South Africa as they clash in a highly-anticipated match. With both teams having been through the maze of regional competition before, this will no doubt be a memorable encounter.

South Africa's head coach, Stuart Baxter, has had his fair share of disappointments while leading his country to the brink of failure years ago. His team is determined not to let that happen again. The Seychelles, on the other hand, have shown resilience time and time again but will need to prove themselves once more if they are to claim victory against South Africa.

Both teams have had some success in recent years, but this match will be all about determination and skill as they face each other head-on. It promises to be a closely fought battle between two of the best teams in the region.

In February, Mauritius play the Seychelles before Madagascar, who beat South Africa 2-0 in Curepipe, takes on Mauritius in a double-header. Two winners move to August for the final tournament held in Lusaka, Zambia will host Lesotho, Malawi and Swaziland in June."

South Africa faces Seychelles first, followed by Mauritius vs. Madagascar. The winners meet the next day, with the group champion advancing to the final mini-tournament in August. stablelm2:1.6b: South Africa returns to the failed match against Mauritius in the Cosafa Cup, facing Seychelles. The new regional competition has changed format due to Seychelles' entry; teams are divided into groups and play knock-out matches. Mauritius hosts the first group with Madagascar, South Africa, and Seychelles as opponents. Winners advance to the final matches in each group, then meet again for the group winners' match. The third group is hosted by Zambia in June, with Lesotho, Malawi, Swaziland, and Angola participating. The champions from these mini-tournaments join title holders Angola in August for the ultimate tournament.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In the upcoming Cosafa Cup, South Africa's top-ranked team returns to Mauritius, where they will face the Seychelles on 26 February. This year, the tournament has expanded from eight to 13 teams due to the inclusion of the Seychelles, with groups of four and knockout matches to determine group champions. The first group features Mauritius (Madagascar, Seychelles, South Africa), while Namibia hosts the second group (Zimbabwe, Botswana, Mozambique) in April. In June, Zambia will host the third group (Lesotho, Malawi, Swaziland). The winners of each group and title holders Angola will advance to a final mini-tournament in August, where the champions will be crowned.
